dataset.title: Dominant” ants favored over “Discoverer” ants inside human settlements

abstract.para: Increased biodiversity loss caused by humans underlines the importance of monitoring the health of ecosystems. One efficient way to do this is through the use of indicator species. Ants show potential as an indicator taxon, but the effect of human disturbance on their communities has not yet been well studied. In natural communities, ant species specialize to varying degrees in either discovery of food resources or aggressive domination of them, but this pattern has not been investigated in the context of human development. In order to find out whether human settlements lead to changes in ant community composition and discovery/dominance dynamics, we set 38 baited traps in matched pairs inside and outside of human settlements. We identified the responding ant genera, recorded activity levels every 10 minutes for one hour, recorded time of discovery and aggressive dominance interactions. “Discoverer” genera occurred at higher frequencies at sites outside human settlements, and “Dominant” genera occurred at higher frequencies at sites inside human settlements. Across all genera, ants arrived to bait traps faster outside of settlements than in them. High beta diversity was observed between inside and outside experimental sites, therefore human settlement at the level of the Leokwe Camp in Mapungubwe National Park appears to change the composition of ant communities. In resource-rich human areas there seems to be less pressure to discover food resources quickly, but increased pressure to defend resources from competitors.

keywordSet.keyword: SANParks, South Africa, Mapungibwe National Park, South Africa

section.title: Methods
section.para: Our study was conducted in Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site located in the Limpopo Province of South Africa (Figure 1). The park is situated along the Limpopo River within the Limpopo basin bordered by Botswana and Zimbabwe. The geology primarily consists of granitic basement rocks which over millions of years eroded to produce present day sandstone formations (Huffman 2005). Tectonic activity caused magma from the earth’s core to rise to the surface resulting in basalt sheets and dolerite dykes. The park is within a savanna biome, consisting of a high diversity of Acacia and Commiphora species; other vegetation in the area includes short, dense, shrubby Mopanes, fever trees, Ana trees, leadwoods, fig trees and sparse tufted grassveld. There are also some very large baobabs scattered in the area (http://www.sanparks.org/parks/mapungubwe/conservation/ff/vegetation.php). The Mapungubwe National Park was established recently in 2004 (www.southafrica.info/ess_info/sa_glance/fauna_flora/mapungubwe-nationalpark.htm), with a tourist resort containing 20 huts for accommodation and an entertainment and dining facility in the Leokwe Camp.
FIGURE 1: Location of Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site (www.sanparks.org/parks/mapungubwe/images/maps/map2.png)

To establish if there were differences in ant communities inside and outside of human settlements, we used bait traps of canned chunk-light tuna in water. To ensure that vegetation type remained constant throughout our experiment, nineteen paired tests consisting of traps positioned inside and outside of human settlements were conducted at six sites. The sites selected for our baited traps are subject to frequent human utilization and therefore commonly contain human-derived food sources. The kitchen garbage is probably the most resource-rich site, as substantial quantities of new food are added daily when groups are present at the camp, and the food may remain in place for up to a week before removal. The dining and entertainment area is almost as rich in resources, as visitors to the camp often consume meals or snacks at the pool or on the lookout deck. A often-used path to the kitchen and entertainment area was also used for one of the sites representing human settlements. The huts represent the highest variability in human utilization, as it is unclear how often each hut is inhabited.

Sites outside settlements were paired to an adjacent inside site by being placed approximately 20 – 30 meters away from the inside site. Traps were set 6 times daily over a period of four days, each test lasting for duration 60 minutes.

To determine the ant genera that used or approached the food resource, specimens were collected in vials for identification. We monitored the interactions between genera and temporal differences in the use of food resources inside and outside of human settlements to investigate if certain genera displayed dominance over the resource. The arrival time of each ant genus and the time it took for a genus to swarm the bait was noted. A swarm was considered a high level of activity and movement maintained by a large number of ants on the bait. The changes in resource utilization over 60 minutes were determined by qualitatively rating activity levels as high, medium, or low at 10 minute intervals for each genus. Further, to establish if certain genera display dominance by aggressive behavior, we continuously monitored and noted any aggressive incidental behaviors and recorded all interactions with other genera while recording activity levels.

To establish which ant genera were present but not necessarily seen at our trial stations we determined the taxonomic composition around the study sites using a grid network of bait traps spaced 15 meters apart. After the traps had been set for one hour, specimens at each trap were collected for identification and a GPS location recorded.

To determine if significantly different ant communities exist between areas inside and outside of human settlements an ANOSIM analysis was run in Primer (Primer- E ltd. 2001). A Pearson’s chi-square test was used to test whether the common “Dominant” (pheidone, tapinoma) and “Discoverer” (monomordium) genera were evenly distributed inside and outside of human settlements. Another Pearson’s chi-square test was used to test the null hypothesis that genus did not affect resource utilization over time. A series of t-tests were used to test for significant differences in the arrival time of common genera. A paired t-test was used to compare the arrival time inside and outside for all trials in which a genus arrived both inside and outside in order to determine if human settlements were responsible for changes in arrival time. Finally, a Pearson’s chi-squared analysis was used to determine if aggressive dominance interactions were distributed evenly across sites inside and outside human settlements.
